p.s: Description of Listeria ivanovii sp. nov.
Listeria ivanovii (i.van.ov'i.i. M.L. gen. noun ivanovii of Ivanov, honoring Ivan Ivanov, a Bulgarian microbiolgist)
Cells are small, nonsporing, gram-positive rods which are motile at 28°C.

Colonies on tryptose agar (Difco Laboratories) are very small (0.5 to 1 mm in diameter after 1 or 2 days of incubation at 37°C), regular, and smooth and appear blueish green when they are viewed by obliquely transmitted light.
Colonies on sheep or horse blood (5%, vol/vol) agar are strongly phemolytic.
A positive CAMP test is exhibited with R. equi (strain CIP 5869) but not with Staphylococcus aureus.
Growth occurs at 4°C within 5 days.
Facultatively anaerobic.
Catalase is produced.
The oxidase test is negative.
Acid but no gas is produced from glucose and D-xylose.
No acid is produced from D-mannitol, L-rhamnose, or α-methyl-D-mannoside.
Voges-Proskauer and methyl red tests are positive.
Esculin is hydrolyzed in 1 day.
Urea is not hydrolyzed.
Gelatin is not hydrolyzed.
Neither indole nor H2S is produced.
Nitrates are not reduced to nitrite.
Strains possess a distinctive antigenic composition referred to as serological group 5.
The 50% lethal dose for holoxenic pathogen-free mice is between 1 x 105 and 3 x 106 colony-forming units per ml.
Pathogenic for animals, especially for pregnant sheep; the species has also been isolated from healthy animals and human carriers and from the environment.
The guanine-plus-cytosine content of the deoxyribonucleic acid is 38 mol% (determined by melting temperature).
The type strain is SLCC 2379 (= ATCC 19119).
This strain was isolated by I.
Ivanov from sheep.
